explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified into Category 2 since flash point 2 degC (closed-cup) (HSDB (2002)) and 6 degC (closed-cup) (Hommel (1996)) are <23 degC, and initial boiling point 97.2 degC (Merck (14th, 2006)) is >35 degC.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is 512 degC (Lide (88th, 2008)) exceeding 70 degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance does not contain oxygen, fluorine or chlorine.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on LD50 values of 39 mg/kg and 50 - 100 mg/kg for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)) correspond to Category 2 and Category 3, respectively, the lower value was adopted and the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 0.21 mL/kg (conversion values with specific gravity: 163.8 mg/kg) for rabbits (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on a LC50 value (1 hour) of 163 ppm (4-hour equivalent: 81.5 ppm) for mice (HSDB (2002)), the substance was classified into Category 1. Since the LC50 value was lower than 90% of saturated vapour pressure concentration (62368.4 ppmV), the classification criteria for gas (ppm) was adopted.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on descriptions of "not caused severe damage" in a rabbit skin application test and "slightly irritating" in a guinea pig test (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified as "Not classified" in JIS Classification (corresponding to Category 3 in GHS classification). In addition, there is a result of "mild irritating" in a Draize test where 500 mg was applied to rabbits for 24-hour (RTECS (2002)).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on reports of "irritating to eye" as human health effects (HSDB (2002)) and "not caused severe damage" in a rabbit eye application test (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 2. As relevant information, there is a result of "moderate irritating" in a rabbit Draize test (RTECS (2002)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data from in vivo mutagenicity tests. From in vitro mutagenicity tests, there are reports of a negative Ames test, a negative CHO cells chromosomal aberration test and a negative sister chromatid exchange analysis (NTP DB (access on Sep. 2009)).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: From Carcinogenicity Studies (Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (2006), there is a result that "In a 104-week inhalation test with rats and mice, exposure of propanenitrile did not increase the incidence of any tumor in male or female F344/DuCrj (Fischer) rats and then there was no evidence of carcinogenic activity. For Crj:BDF1 mice, there was no evidence of carcinogenic activity since no increase in incidence of any tumor was observed in either sex". Therefore the substance was classified as "Not classified".

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on a report that embryonic death and fetal toxicity were observed in an inhalation developmental toxicity test with rats at a dose at which general toxicity was not manifested in parental animals (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 1B.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (systemic toxicity, central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Since there are human case reports that a worker exposed to the substance via inhalation and dermal contact showed loss of consciousness, respiratory alkalosis and metabolic acidosis, and that 2 workers inhaled the substance with 1 worker exhibiting symptoms of headache, nausea and dizziness 2-hour after exposure and the second worker collapsing 7-hour after exposure (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 1 (systemic toxicity, central nervous system).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Although there is report that changes in urine composition and erythrocyte count, weight loss or decreased weight gain were observed at 209 ppm (0.47 mg/L) in a mouse 14-week inhalation test (RTECS (2002), original literature: Toxicologist. (Conference Paper in Society of Toxicology) Vol. 5, p.113, 1985), classification was not possible due to lack of the detailed data. As relevant information, the respiratory system, cardiovascular system, central nervous system, liver, kidneys are listed as target organ in NIOSH Pocket Guide to Chemical Hazards (2005).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Not classified from its 96h-LC50 = 1520 mg/L for fish (Fathead minnow) (HSDB, 2002; AQUIRE, 2010).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Not classified since its acute toxicity is Not classified and it is not non-water soluble from water solubility = 100,000 mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2010).
